title: Psalms Chapter 68 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 68 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 68 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 68.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:1, what should happen to God's enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: They should be scattered
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:1 says, 'Let God arise, let his enemies be scattered,' indicating that God's enemies are to be scattered.

questions.question: Psalms 68:4 mentions praising God by what name?
questions.correctAnswer: JAH
questions.explanation: Verse 4 instructs to extol Him by the name JAH, who rideth upon the heavens.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 68:6, God brings out those who are bound with chains.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:6 states, 'he bringeth out those which are bound with chains,' confirming this is true.

questions.question: What natural event happened when God went before His people, according to Psalms 68:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The earth shook
questions.explanation: Verse 8 says, 'The earth shook, the heavens also dropped at the presence of God,' showing the earth shook.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:10, for whom has God prepared goodness?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states God has prepared goodness for the poor.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 68:11: 'The Lord gave the ______: great was the company of those that published it.'
questions.correctAnswer: word
questions.explanation: Verse 11 clearly says, 'The Lord gave the word,' making 'word' the correct answer.

questions.question: Who fled according to Psalms 68:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Kings of armies
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states, 'Kings of armies did flee apace,' indicating that kings of armies fled.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 68:17 mentions that the chariots of God are twenty thousand and thousands of angels.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 17 says, 'The chariots of God are twenty thousand, even thousands of angels,' confirming this statement.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:18, what has God done after ascending on high?
questions.correctAnswer: Led captivity captive
questions.explanation: Verse 18 states, 'Thou hast ascended on high, thou hast led captivity captive.'

questions.question: Who daily loadeth us with benefits according to Psalms 68:19?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: Verse 19 blesses the Lord who daily loads us with benefits.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:21, what will God do to the head of His enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: Wound it
questions.explanation: Verse 21 says, 'But God shall wound the head of his enemies,' indicating the correct answer is to wound it.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:22, from where will God bring His people again?
questions.correctAnswer: Bashan
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states, 'I will bring again from Bashan, I will bring my people again from the depths of the sea.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 68:26 commands to bless God from the fountain of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 26 says, 'Bless ye God in the congregations, even the Lord, from the fountain of Israel.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:29, why shall kings bring presents unto God?
options: Because of thy temple at Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Because of thy temple at Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verse 29 states, 'Because of thy temple at Jerusalem shall kings bring presents unto thee.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:35, what does the God of Israel give to His people?
questions.correctAnswer: Strength and power
questions.explanation: Verse 35 says, 'the God of Israel is he that giveth strength and power unto his people.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 68 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 68 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of opposition and enemies. Based on Psalms 68, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in such trials?
options: God arises and scatters His enemies, causing those who hate Him to flee
We must rely solely on our own strength to overcome adversaries
Enemies will always prevail despite our faith
God is indifferent to our struggles
questions.correctAnswer: God arises and scatters His enemies, causing those who hate Him to flee
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:1 teaches that God arises and scatters His enemies, and those who hate Him flee before Him. This encourages believers to trust God's power over opposition. Supporting verses include Psalms 68:2-3, which emphasize God’s presence causes wicked to perish and the righteous to rejoice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 68 instruct believers to respond in worship when reflecting on God's greatness and protection?
options: Sing praises and rejoice exceedingly before God
Avoid singing as it is distracting
Focus only on personal needs without praise
questions.correctAnswer: Sing praises and rejoice exceedingly before God
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:3-4 encourages the righteous to be glad and rejoice exceedingly, and to sing praises to God's name. This shows worship through joyful praise is a proper response to God's greatness and protection.

questions.question: A believer feels isolated and lonely. According to Psalms 68, what truth about God's care and provision can encourage them?
options: God sets the solitary in families and brings freedom to those bound
Loneliness is a permanent state without hope
God ignores those who feel isolated
Only people can provide companionship, not God
questions.correctAnswer: God sets the solitary in families and brings freedom to those bound
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:6 reveals that God provides for the solitary by placing them in families and liberates those in bondage, offering hope and community to those feeling isolated. This emphasizes God's personal care.

questions.question: What does Psalms 68 say about God's role toward orphans and widows, and how should that influence a believer’s attitude toward caring for vulnerable people?
options: God is a father to the fatherless and a judge of widows, calling us to reflect His care
God is distant from the needs of orphans and widows
Only the government should care for vulnerable people
Vulnerability is a sign of personal failure
questions.correctAnswer: God is a father to the fatherless and a judge of widows, calling us to reflect His care
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:5 describes God as a father to the fatherless and judge of widows, highlighting His special concern. Believers are thus encouraged to imitate God's compassion and justice for vulnerable individuals.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about sharing the gospel. According to Psalms 68, what encouragement is given about evangelism?
options: The Lord gave the word and a great company published it
Only a few people are called to share the gospel
Sharing the gospel is unnecessary in difficult times
Evangelism should be done only by clergy
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord gave the word and a great company published it
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:11 highlights that the Lord gave the word and many proclaimed it, encouraging believers to actively participate in evangelism, trusting God's empowerment and purpose.

questions.question: How does Psalms 68 describe God's provision for the poor, and what principle about generosity does this suggest for believers?
options: God prepares goodness for the poor, indicating believers should do likewise
The poor are responsible for their own needs alone
Generosity is optional and not important
Only the rich benefit from God's blessings
questions.correctAnswer: God prepares goodness for the poor, indicating believers should do likewise
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:10 states that God prepares goodness for the poor, suggesting that believers are called to reflect God’s generosity by caring for those in need.

questions.question: A believer is facing spiritual warfare and temptation. What truth from Psalms 68 offers hope about God's power and presence in such struggles?
options: The chariots of God are thousands of angels, and the Lord is among them
Believers must face spiritual battles alone
God allows evil to triumph without intervention
Spiritual warfare is a myth and irrelevant
questions.correctAnswer: The chariots of God are thousands of angels, and the Lord is among them
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:17 affirms God's mighty presence with thousands of angels, reassuring believers of divine protection and power in spiritual battles.

questions.question: How does Psalms 68 encourage believers to respond with gratitude amid daily blessings and deliverance?
options: Bless the Lord who daily loads us with benefits
Take blessings for granted without thanks
questions.correctAnswer: Bless the Lord who daily loads us with benefits
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:19 invites believers to bless the Lord who provides daily benefits and salvation, encouraging a lifestyle of gratitude and recognition of God's ongoing care.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 68 teaches that God only gives salvation to the righteous and never interacts with the rebellious.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:18 says God received gifts even for the rebellious so that the LORD might dwell among them, showing God’s grace extends beyond the righteous to include those who repent.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 68, believers should expect God to empower them and give strength in their daily lives.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:35 states God gives strength and power to His people, encouraging believers to rely on His empowerment for daily living and perseverance.

questions.question: A church leader wants to encourage the congregation in fellowship and worship. According to Psalms 68, how should the people engage in worship together?
options: Singers and instrumental players lead, with everyone participating joyfully
Only a select few should worship publicly
Worship should be silent and individual only
Instruments should be avoided in worship
questions.correctAnswer: Singers and instrumental players lead, with everyone participating joyfully
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:25 describes singers going before and players on instruments following, with damsels playing timbrels, illustrating active, joyful corporate worship.

questions.question: A believer desires to live with integrity and humility. How does Psalms 68 illustrate God’s power over enemies that encourages humble trust rather than prideful confidence?
options: God wounds the head of His enemies and scatters those who delight in war
Believers should boast in their own strength
Victory comes from human schemes only
questions.correctAnswer: God wounds the head of His enemies and scatters those who delight in war
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:21 and 30 show God’s sovereign power to defeat enemies and scatter the warlike, encouraging believers to trust God humbly rather than rely on prideful self-confidence.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 68 says, "Bless ye God in the congregations, even the Lord, from the fountain of _____."
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:26 commands blessing God from the fountain of Israel, emphasizing communal worship from the heart of God's people.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 68, how should believers view the presence of God in their lives, especially in relation to trials and deliverance?
options: God’s presence causes mountains to leap and sustains His people forever
God is distant and uninvolved in daily struggles
Deliverance is unrelated to God's presence
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence causes mountains to leap and sustains His people forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:15-16 portrays the hill of God as desired for dwelling forever and challenges high hills to leap, symbolizing God’s active presence sustaining His people through trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 68 encourage believers to demonstrate faithfulness in their work and stewardship?
options: God commands strength for what He has wrought, and kings bring presents because of His temple
Work and stewardship are unimportant compared to prayer only
We should rely on luck rather than diligence
Stewardship is only for church leaders
questions.correctAnswer: God commands strength for what He has wrought, and kings bring presents because of His temple
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:28-29 show God commands strength to uphold His work and that kings bring gifts because of His temple, encouraging faithful, diligent stewardship and work honoring God.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 68 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 68.

questions.question: In Psalms 68:1, what is the immediate action requested to God regarding His enemies?
options: Let God arise and scatter His enemies
Let God hide from His enemies
Let God speak peace to His enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Let God arise and scatter His enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:1 explicitly calls for God to arise and scatter His enemies, emphasizing divine victory and protection.

questions.question: The imagery of smoke and wax melting in Psalms 68:2 serves as a metaphor for what?
options: The destruction of the wicked at God's presence
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of the wicked at God's presence
questions.explanation: Verse 2 uses smoke driven away and wax melting before fire as vivid metaphors for the wicked perishing before God's presence.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:5, God is described as which of the following roles?
options: A father of the fatherless and judge of the widows
questions.correctAnswer: A father of the fatherless and judge of the widows
questions.explanation: Verse 5 highlights God's care for the vulnerable, presenting Him as a father to orphans and a judge for widows, emphasizing social justice.

questions.question: What does Psalms 68:6 state about those who are solitary and those who are rebellious?
options: God sets the solitary in families, but the rebellious dwell in a dry land
God leaves the solitary to wander, but blesses the rebellious
The solitary are punished, and the rebellious are exalted
Both solitary and rebellious are given riches
questions.correctAnswer: God sets the solitary in families, but the rebellious dwell in a dry land
questions.explanation: This verse contrasts God's provision for the lonely with the fate of the rebellious, showing divine justice and care.

questions.question: The shaking of the earth and heavens and the movement of Sinai in Psalms 68:8 is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Apocalyptic imagery
questions.explanation: The vivid description of cosmic disturbances at God's presence evokes apocalyptic imagery common in prophetic and poetic texts.

questions.question: How does Psalms 68:9 relate to the theme of divine provision in the wilderness?
options: God sent plentiful rain to confirm His inheritance when it was weary
God provided manna for the people
God made water flow from the rock
God protected the people from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God sent plentiful rain to confirm His inheritance when it was weary
questions.explanation: This verse recalls God's provision by sending rain, symbolizing restoration and confirmation of the land as His inheritance.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'chariots of God' and 'thousands of angels' mentioned in Psalms 68:17?
options: They represent divine armies accompanying God
They are literal chariots used in battle
questions.correctAnswer: They represent divine armies accompanying God
questions.explanation: Verse 17 uses 'chariots of God' and 'thousands of angels' to depict God's heavenly hosts, indicating His majesty and power in battle.

questions.question: Psalms 68:18 speaks of God ascending on high and leading captivity captive. Which New Testament passage most directly references this event?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephesians 4:8
questions.explanation: Ephesians 4:8 quotes Psalms 68:18, referring to Christ's ascension and His victory over captivity, fulfilling the typology.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:19, how is the Lord described in relation to daily benefits?
options: The Lord daily loads us with benefits
The Lord withholds blessings until needed
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord daily loads us with benefits
questions.explanation: Verse 19 praises the Lord for daily blessing His people abundantly, emphasizing continuous divine grace.

questions.question: The phrase 'God of salvation' in Psalms 68:20 carries what implication about God’s character?
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly calls God the 'God of salvation,' affirming His role as the deliverer and source of life beyond death.

questions.question: In Psalms 68:22, God promises to bring His people again from which two locations?
options: Bashan and the depths of the sea
questions.correctAnswer: Bashan and the depths of the sea
questions.explanation: Verse 22 specifically mentions Bashan and the depths of the sea as symbolic places from which God will restore His people.

questions.question: Which tribe is mentioned first among the princes in Psalms 68:27, indicating its significance?
questions.correctAnswer: Benjamin
questions.explanation: Verse 27 lists Benjamin first among the princes, possibly highlighting its prominent role in the congregation or tradition.

questions.question: What literary device is used in Psalms 68:13’s comparison of lying 'among the pots' to becoming 'as the wings of a dove covered with silver'?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The verse uses 'as' to make a direct comparison, a hallmark of simile, to illustrate transformation and honor.

questions.question: Psalms 68:31 mentions Ethiopia stretching out her hands unto God. How does this reflect the theme of universal worship found throughout Scripture?
options: It shows Gentile nations coming to worship the God of Israel
It limits worship only to Israel
It forbids foreign nations from worship
It refers only to historical battles
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Gentile nations coming to worship the God of Israel
questions.explanation: This verse anticipates the inclusion of Gentile nations in worship, a theme echoed in Isaiah and the New Testament.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:33, what is the nature of God's voice?
options: A mighty voice sent out from the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: A mighty voice sent out from the heavens
questions.explanation: Verse 33 describes God’s voice as mighty and powerful, reinforcing His sovereignty over heaven and earth.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 68 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 68 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:5, how is God described in relation to the vulnerable?
options: A father of the fatherless and a judge of the widows
A warrior who fights for the oppressed
A king who reigns with justice
questions.correctAnswer: A father of the fatherless and a judge of the widows
questions.explanation: Psalms 68:5 explicitly describes God as 'A father of the fatherless, and a judge of the widows,' emphasizing His care for the vulnerable. This aligns with other Scriptures such as Deuteronomy 10:18, James 1:27, Isaiah 1:17, and Psalm 146:9, which affirm God's protective justice toward orphans and widows.

questions.question: What does Psalm 68:18 say God did after ascending on high?
options: He led captivity captive and received gifts for men, including the rebellious
He created the heavens and the earth
He judged the nations with justice
He sent down the Holy Spirit upon the apostles
questions.correctAnswer: He led captivity captive and received gifts for men, including the rebellious
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:18 speaks of God ascending on high, leading captivity captive, and receiving gifts for men, including the rebellious, showing His victory over sin and death. This connects with Ephesians 4:8-10, Luke 4:18, and Acts 2:33, which describe Christ's ascension and the giving of spiritual gifts.

questions.question: In Psalms 68:19, how is God described in relation to daily blessings?
options: The Lord who daily loads us with benefits, the God of our salvation
The Creator who sustains all things by His power
The righteous judge who punishes the wicked
The King who reigns over all the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord who daily loads us with benefits, the God of our salvation
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:19 blesses the Lord as the one who daily loads us with benefits and is the God of our salvation. This reflects God's continual grace and provision, consistent with Lamentations 3:22-23, Philippians 4:19, Hebrews 7:25, and Psalm 23:1-3.

questions.question: What does Psalms 68:6 teach about God's care for the lonely and captives?
options: God sets the solitary in families and brings out those bound with chains
God leaves the rebellious to wander in dry lands without hope
God punishes the solitary by isolating them further
God ignores the plight of captives
questions.correctAnswer: God sets the solitary in families and brings out those bound with chains
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:6 highlights God's restorative work: setting the solitary in families and freeing captives, demonstrating His heart for redemption and community. Scripture parallels include Isaiah 61:1, Luke 4:18, Galatians 6:2, and Hebrews 13:3.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:17, what is said about the chariots of God?
options: The chariots of God are twenty thousand, thousands of angels
God has only a few angels to serve Him
God's power is limited to Mount Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: The chariots of God are twenty thousand, thousands of angels
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:17 declares that God's chariots are twenty thousand, thousands of angels, portraying God's majestic heavenly host. This is consistent with Hebrews 1:14, 2 Kings 6:16-17, Revelation 5:11, and Psalm 103:20, which affirm angelic hosts serving God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 68:20 describe God in terms of salvation?
options: He is the God of salvation, and the Lord owns the issues from death
He abandons those who die without faith
He is distant and unconcerned about salvation
questions.correctAnswer: He is the God of salvation, and the Lord owns the issues from death
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:20 states God is the God of salvation and that the Lord owns the issues from death, affirming His sovereign power over life and death. This corresponds with John 11:25-26, Romans 6:23, Isaiah 25:8, and 1 Corinthians 15:54-57.

questions.question: In Psalms 68:4, by what name is God extolled as riding upon the heavens?
questions.correctAnswer: JAH
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:4 extols God as the one who rides upon the heavens by the name JAH, a shortened form of Yahweh signifying God's majestic presence. This name appears also in Exodus 15:2, Isaiah 12:2, Revelation 19:6, and Psalm 89:8, emphasizing God's eternal sovereignty.

questions.question: What does Psalms 68:21 say God will do to the head of His enemies?
options: God shall wound the head of his enemies and the hairy scalp of those who persist in trespasses
God will forgive all enemies without judgment
God will ignore those who trespass
God will bless even those who rebel
questions.correctAnswer: God shall wound the head of his enemies and the hairy scalp of those who persist in trespasses
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:21 speaks of God's judgment upon His enemies, specifically wounding the head of those who persist in sin. This aligns with Romans 12:19, Psalm 110:6, Proverbs 16:7, and Nahum 1:2, which affirm God's righteous judgment.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:11, what did the Lord give that resulted in a great company publishing it?
questions.correctAnswer: The word
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:11 says the Lord gave the word, and a great company published it, indicating God's revelation and the proclamation of His truth. This is consistent with Isaiah 55:11, Romans 10:17, 2 Timothy 4:2, and Acts 2:14-41 where the word is preached widely.

questions.question: What does Psalms 68:14 describe happening when the Almighty scattered kings in Salmon?
questions.correctAnswer: It was white as snow
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:14 describes the scattering of kings in Salmon as being 'white as snow,' symbolizing divine judgment and cleansing. Similar imagery is found in Isaiah 1:18, Daniel 2:35, Psalm 51:7, and Revelation 1:14 regarding God's power to purify and judge.

questions.question: Psalms 68:1 calls for God to arise. What is the immediate effect described?
options: His enemies are scattered and those who hate Him flee
The heavens open and rain falls
questions.correctAnswer: His enemies are scattered and those who hate Him flee
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:1 calls for God to arise so that His enemies be scattered and haters flee, illustrating God's victorious power over opposition. This theme is echoed in Exodus 15:3, Nahum 1:3, 2 Thessalonians 1:6-7, and Revelation 19:11.

questions.question: What does Psalm 68:8 say happened to the earth and Sinai at God's presence?
options: The earth shook, the heavens dropped, and Sinai was moved
They were filled with light and peace
questions.correctAnswer: The earth shook, the heavens dropped, and Sinai was moved
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:8 describes the earth shaking, heavens dropping, and Sinai moving at God's presence, revealing His awesome and fearful power. This is consistent with Exodus 19:18, Hebrews 12:26-29, Joel 2:10, and Psalm 97:4.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:24-25, who led and followed in the procession of praise?
options: Singers went before, players on instruments followed, and damsels played timbrels
Kings led the procession, followed by priests
Prophets led the way, with warriors in the rear
Priests went before, and elders followed
questions.correctAnswer: Singers went before, players on instruments followed, and damsels played timbrels
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:24-25 describes a procession where singers went before, instrumentalists followed, and damsels played timbrels, illustrating a joyful, ordered worship. This parallels 2 Chronicles 5:13, 1 Chronicles 15:16, Exodus 15:20, and Psalm 150:4-6.

questions.question: What does Psalms 68:31 predict about nations like Egypt and Ethiopia?
options: Princes shall come out of Egypt; Ethiopia will stretch out hands to God
They will reject God and face destruction
They will remain isolated from Israel
They will conquer Israel and rule the land
questions.correctAnswer: Princes shall come out of Egypt; Ethiopia will stretch out hands to God
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:31 prophesies that princes from Egypt and Ethiopia will come to God, indicating the inclusion of Gentile nations in worship. This is echoed in Isaiah 45:14, Psalm 87:4, Acts 8:27-28, and Revelation 7:9 regarding Gentile salvation.

questions.question: According to Psalms 68:28, what is the prayer directed to God concerning His strength?
options: Strengthen, O God, that which thou hast wrought for us
Take away all power from our enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Strengthen, O God, that which thou hast wrought for us
questions.explanation: Psalm 68:28 petitions God to strengthen what He has wrought for His people, emphasizing dependence on divine empowerment. This aligns with Nehemiah 2:18, Isaiah 40:29, Philippians 4:13, and Ephesians 3:16.
